sentence: Gwyneth Paltrow 's Goop holiday gift guide for 2017 - parts of it ridiculous by design, all of it pricey as a broadly accepted trait - includes a "toxics-free" casserole dish ($1,220), gold Louboutin baby shoes ($250), at-home, spa-style float tank ($16,500) and "personal yellow submarine" (price upon request).

[ibd-display-video id=2065538 width=50 float=left autostart=true] Most Americans aren't flush enough to shell out for the Hollywood A lister's recommendations, but they are nevertheless out in force, spending major amounts of cash for Christmas.
But much like the contrast between Gwyneth and the vaster hoi polloi, however, there's a noticeable gap between the haves and have-nots this holiday season.
Analysts expect the Big Six retail names: Amazon.com ( AMZN ), Home Depot ( HD ), Walmart ( WMT ), Costco ( COST ), Lowe's ( LOW ) and Kroger (KR), to command the bulk of shopping trends this season.
Indeed, the National Retail Federation predicts holiday sales to reach $678.8 billion to $682 billion, 3.6% to 4% over 2016 holiday sales.

Black Friday gave a strong kick-off to the spending season, and Cyber Monday was the biggest online shopping day, ever, period, said Adobe Analytics, which forecasts a total of $107.4 billion in online sales to be rung up over the last two months of 2017.
To predict, even in mid-December, that Amazon will mount this year's winner's podium seems like a no-brainer.

"Our analysis suggests AMZN is driving 40%-50% of overall U.S. retail sales growth as e-commerce gains share within retail and Amazon gains share within e-commerce," wrote Morgan Stanley equity analyst Kimberly Greenberger at the start of November, rating Amazon as one of two top picks for the season.
Driving her bullishness on Amazon are its large user base, "strong" Prime membership revenue growth and Echo device sales figures.
ACSI Funds Chief Strategist Kevin Quigg also has the company pegged as a holiday leader, thanks to Amazon's ability to worm its way into people's lives via Prime and its reliably quick shipping.
But the rewards are not being spread equally among retailers, despite the low unemployment rate, 17-year high consumer confidence level and upwardly marching stock market.

In fact, this could be the first year since the 2008-09 recession era that softline retailers (read: clothing stores, primarily) see a fourth-quarter year-over-year sales decline, according to Morgan Stanley.
Greenberger expects a 0.4% comparable dip, down from 2016's 0.2% year-over-year gain.
She blames her bearish position on a number of things: poor weather, higher gas prices and a ramp in online shopping, as well as rising expenses and shipping costs.
She also asserts that the price tag on Apple's [ticker symb= (AAPL)] iPhone X could pinch budgets that might've otherwise allowed for a few new sweaters and dresses.

IBD'S TAKE:If you want to understand the state of the market, read IBD's Stock Market Today columns throughout the market day, and the end-of-day The Big Picture ( take a free trial ) for timely market analysis and highlighted growth stocks breaking out of proper bases.
Hardline retailers merit a cautious outlook, partly due to possible headwinds from rising gasoline prices - a traditional damper for sales results.
"A greater share of spending will likely be concentrated among the Big Six," she said, "leaving fewer dollars for other retailers."
The Big Six, beyond Amazon, are big box and home improvement stores, a grocery chain and a membership store, none of which sound terribly romantic.
Tiffany & Co (TIF) they are not.
But all are apparently proving to be good sources for Christmas shopping, particularly as the mall, a once-traditional destination for gift buyers, struggles to make an argument for its existence.
"People think of Costco as 20-gallon drums of ketchup," said ACSI Funds' Quigg, who uses customer satisfaction metrics to formulate his winners-and-losers list.
"But increasingly they have good electronics and jewelry, and they have other sorts of items that are more popular for the holiday season.
And while a lot of people are continuing to shop online, there is something to be said for the in-store experience."
That precious in-store experience is something malls are trying to make over, thanks to the younger generation's preference for experiences over material goods.
Retail Metrics President Ken Perkins expects mall operators to continue to add entertainment and services as magnets for foot traffic.

Still, more debt is coming due over the next two to three years, Perkins told Investor's Business Daily, and "the retail environment is not strong enough to grow sales to offset some of the loan payments that are coming for some of these retailers."
That result could point to more retail bankruptcies in 2018.
Certainly, this year has not been kind to retailers : The Limited, Payless ShoeSource, Toys 'R' Us are among those having filed for bankruptcy protection.
Perkins also warned against assuming that a better holiday season will translate to profits come earnings season.
Even as Macy's increases its holiday hiring, suggesting that business is picking up, he said that doesn't necessarily change the long-term prospects for the ailing department store segment.
Easy year-over-year comparisons and lower expectations are making life a little easier for some mall-based apparel stocks.
Express (EXPR) has more than doubled in price since August, but remains far below its April 2016 high.
Gap (GPS), driven by Old Navy, has soared almost 60% since July.
Collectively, apparel and shoe retailers are up 27% since late August, an advance that lifted the apparel/shoes group on Thursday to a No.
10 ranking among the 197 industries tracked by IBD .

But the rally among retail names has a great deal more to do with expectations of tax reform legislation than anything else, Perkins said, pointing to the downsizing of corporate tax rates from mid- to high-30s to the low 20s.
Quigg has Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF) and Nordstrom (JWN) - a once-hot mall clothier and and the upscale department store - on his "losers" list.
Also on that list is Target (TGT), one of the big-box stores that has earned mixed reviews from analysts.
"Based upon our analysis, they just seem sort of average at everything," he said.
Perkins feels the opposite, pointing to the investments it has made and the market share opportunities ahead.
Target announced Wednesday the acquisition of same-day delivery service Shipt for $550 million in cash .

Walmart, meanwhile, merits a literal "meh" from Quigg, who argues that retailers unable to draw cash from robust membership programs (think Amazon Prime, Costco) increasingly rely on price-cutting measures, which isn't a sustainable competitive advantage.
Plus, the mega brick-and-mortar retailer ranks low on ACSI's customer satisfaction survey.
Still, Wall Street likes Walmart's moves, particularly in the wake of last year's Jet.com acquisition and its slew of e-commerce acquisitions this year.
The overarching narrative thus far appears to be that Walmart is holding its own in the retail battle against Amazon.

Perkins hailed off-price retailers, such as TJX (TJX), Ross Stores (ROST) and Burlington Stores (BURL) as "positioned in the sweet spot of the economy," a market ripe for upper-middle-income, bargain-hunting individuals.
Ross' stock price is up 45% since July.
Morgan Stanley's Greenberger also likes Burlington - besides Amazon, as her other top pick for the holiday retail period.
Burlington shares are up 39% since August.
Here's one other, perhaps unexpected pick for the win column this season: eBay (EBAY).
"We think flying under the radar is eBay," said ACSI Funds' Quigg.
"They're not going to do near the scale that Amazon's going to do.
That being said, our proprietary rankings have them pretty strong."

He likened the online marketplace, which is still trying to shed its brand image as an auction site for odd and used items, to an early Amazon, when it was still trying to make the shift from an online bookstore to a seller of goods and services.
"(EBay has) the infrastructure to do it, they have for quite some time; (it's) just getting people to recognize that they are a viable competitor to Amazon," said Quigg.
"There's a tremendous opportunity for them to do that."
